Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2009 10:18AM artsci1 wrote: Hi floridian, I don't think that you should ignore the other two lumps.  Yes, they could be benign, and hopefully they will be, but on the slim chance they are not, then they needed to be treated as soon as possible.  If you had a pre-cancerous condition then a second opinion would be great just as Deidre1 said.  I, personally, got second and third opinions, and then got them taken out - thankfully benign.  However, I don't want to take chances because my sister died of ovarian/uterine cancer when the doctor's thought it was just an infection.  So, I choose/chose the pro-active route because of my family history.  Do what is best for you, unfortunately, even if your mom may not necessarily agree.  Wishing you the best.
Posts.Title: Help- Mom thinks I'm crazy? floridian floridian

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2009 06:22AM artsci1 wrote: zoeylovely, I believe that most states have some type of program that may offer free mammogram screenings.  Also the Susan G. Komen foundation has various locations across the United States and they have free yearly mammograms.  Perhaps do a search under Susan G. Komen locations and give them a call.  They are very helpful I have spoken with them before for someone who had no insurance.  Also I heard that there is another cancer foundation that does free screenings also - can't think of the exact foundation - will try to recall and post back.  Perhaps you can do a search on free breast screenings or mammograms with your state in the search.  Let us know how it goes.  Take care.

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2009 10:30AM artsci1 wrote: Hi Angeltam, Yes, the flu definately makes you feel achey like you have arthritis; I hope you get over the flu quickly!  Did the tech give you any hint if he/she saw the lump(s) when you got the ultrasound?   I hope doctor has some answers for you real soon.  Take care and rest up.  Don't forget the vitamins (smile).  Talk to you soon.
Posts.Title: New info.... angeltam PS73

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2009 11:09AM artsci1 wrote: Hi worried_husband, I know it's hard not to worry, but 80% of lumps are benign.  At first, I had a fine needle aspiration - which doesn't take very much of a tissue sample.  In fact, alot of times the fine needle takes way too small of a sample to see what's really going on.  My results from the fine needle were abnormal/atypical, so I decided to have the core biopsy because it takes far more tissue samples so that the doctors can get a more accurate diagnosis.  Well, my core biopsy came back benign.  So, because the fine needle aspiration and the core biopsy came back giving two different results, I had to end up having surgery.  Core biopsies are quite accurate though.   Surgery is the best way to tell exactly what's happening, especially if there is a conflict, and you don't have to keep wondering if they got enough of a sample.  My results were thankfully, benign.  So, the core biopsy was the correct diagnosis of being benign, and the surgery confirmed that. Please feel free to ask more questions, I'll help the best I can, and if I can't help then I'm sure other ladies on here have far more information than I do.  Take care.
Posts.Title: Core Biopsy - some advice worried_husband NeoPat

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2009 07:56AM artsci1 wrote: Hi worried_husband, I am very happy that your wife's results were benign.!!  You are right, health is so very very important.  Stay happy and healthy!  Take care.

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2010 09:44AM artsci1 wrote: Hi chancesmom, Please don't feel alone.  We are here for you.  I know playing the waiting game sucks!  I went for my yearly screening a couple of months ago, and they found something - AGAIN...the first time they found lumps was a couple of years ago, I ended up getting benign results after a long ordeal. I guess this time I was not expecting them to even see anything because the follow-up mammo after my first surgery gave me the all clear.  Now the imaging place sees something, so they called me back in and stared and pressed on it with the U/S wand for so long that I started getting that sinking feeling in the pit of my stomach...  I then took the images to my breast surgeon about a month ago, and she says that it's really tiny, so she wants to watch it for 6 months, SO more waiting.  I'm glad I trust her.  The last time I was kind of crazed - maybe even more so because my sister had passed away from uterine/ovarian cancer at the age of 42, and that's how old I was when they first saw those lumps...sigh... So, no matter what, please, know that you are not alone.  If you need to talk some more, I am here - we all are Carol
Posts.Title: No surgery today...fluid now leaking from 2 ducts? Chancesmom CrunchyPoodleMama

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2009 11:12AM artsci1 wrote: Hi taraleec, I'm sorry that you have been through all that.  I too have had conflicting results and had the fna which came back as ADH, and then core biopsy which came back benign, so I ended up getting an excisional.  Thankfully, benign results (still not sure how you go from showing ADH to not ! )  I had cysts, fibroadenomas, stromal fibrosis, usual ductal hyperplasia(UDH is one step under ADH) - basically fibrocystic breasts.  I'm not familiar with LCIS and the various treatments for it, however, I pray that your surgery goes well.  Let us know how you are doing.
Posts.Title: Surgery - Finally taraleec Stumped

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2010 05:40PM artsci1 wrote: Hi, I agree with gutsy that it is best to wait til' after your period - your hormones could be a bit out of control right now.  If it's not that, maybe it's possible scar tissue.  Personally, I have "busy" breasts - already had 2 fibroadenomas removed and 2-3 cysts drained about 1 1/2 years ago.  Recently, after mylast mammo and ultrasound, I now have more lumps/cysts.  My radiologist and breast surgeon are watching one in particular; I have to go back in about 2 months for a follow-up on that one.  Maybe you have "busy" breasts also.  Just make sure that you watch it closely, and if you still feel something, then be sure to have it checked. Take care, artsci1
Posts.Title: A new lump? dannabenne artsci1

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2009 11:32AM artsci1 wrote: Hi jah, It does sound like the lump may be due to hormonal change near the time of your period.  I say that because I took my 16 year od daughter to get a couple of lumps checked out.  The ob/gyn and the breast surgeon told her to watch to see if they got smaller after her periods and larger right before her periods, if they did, then that would most likely be hormonal changes.  She was found to have cysts and fibrocystic breasts as I do.  Remember, most lumps are benign.  But, it is always good to go to see a doctor for the correct assesment.
Posts.Title: changing lump w/ period? jah nayia37

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2009 07:45AM artsci1 wrote: Hi kibbles, Fibroadenomas are benign, so try not to worry about them.  I had two removed about a year ago.  It is just something that happens to some women - my daughter who is 16 has one and a couple of cysts.  After you get a certain age: 35 - 40 and on up, quite a few doctor like to take them out to make sure that they are not hiding anything, but the fibroadenoma itself is benign!!  Try to be secure in that fact.  Take care and feel free to ask me any other questions.
Posts.Title: Experiences with fibroadenomas--worried about mine kibbles Beesie

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2009 02:13AM artsci1 wrote: Hi tonya1968, About 6 months ago, I had a lump surgically removed because it looked like it could be cancerous - even the fna and core biopsy contradicted each other.  So they had to do surgery to see what was really going on-I had a fibroadenoma, hyperplasia, along with stromal fibrosis.  Stromal fibrosis can make a lump look malignant even when it is benign. Hopefully yours will be benign also.
Posts.Title: Fibroadenoma or cancer? tonya1968 artsci1

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2010 02:36PM artsci1 wrote: Hi catwood, I was recently called back for more films, and they also gave me an ultrasound.  My breast started hurting hurt so bad  when she was giving me the ultrasound.  She said, "Hasn't this been hurting you?"  I was thinking, "Not til' you started pressing on it for the last 15 min" It was soo sore - I didn't even know anything was there.  She stayed there so long looking at the screen, I was like GEEZ, this must be REALLY BAD!!  My breast was achey and sore for a good 2 1/2 weeks later, I had to take pain medicine.  I did take the films to my breast surgeon, and she wants me to come back in 6 months.  More waiting... By the way,  I had surgery on my breast about 1 1/2 years ago.  I was like a crazy person  through the whole ordeal back then, but it taught me alot!  Thankfully, the results turned out to be benign, but when they first tested the lump, it tested as atypical ductal hyperplasia with the fine needle(perhaps I had a few atypical cells), and it looked possibly cancerous, but after the excisional biopsy, it turned out that I had stromal fibrosis, which can make tissue look malignant. And I also had usual ductal hyperplasia, which is not completely normal, but it's not atypical ductal hyperplasia either.  Talk about a scary time back then, and now I am playing the waiting game again - but I trust my surgeon, and if I feel any changes before the 6 months is up, then I will let her know.  I am wishing you the best - and you know you will always have support here!  artsci1
Posts.Title: STILL WAITING AND PARALYZED catwood Chevfan

Posts.Content: May 9, 2009 05:55PM artsci1 wrote: Hi kayan1, I have dense breast also and lumps that were suspicious, even after the fna and ultrasound biopsy.  The results were conflicitng, so the lumps had to come out.  The lumps were fibroadenomas with usual hyperplasia, but also stromal fibrosis - that's why one of them look malignant.  Stroal fibrosis can make the tissue look malignant, so I will make sure that I get checked regularly and thouroughly.  I'm glad your results were benign also.

Posts.Title: lump on rib Melsyboo belecoi

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2008 03:22PM artsci1 wrote: Hi Barb, I can relate to what you are saying. I had an fna, then core biopsy and then I had a surgical removal of fibroadenomas in the left breast.  I had all those procedures because I had conflicting results - the fna was atypical and then the core biopsy was benign, so they had to break the tie and do surgery.  Fortunately after the surgery, the doctor said it was benign. What's strange is that right after the surgery and for about 1 1/2 months after it, I had hardly any pain.  Now, I have shooting pain in that breast at least 5 times a week.  I mean the kind that can sometimes make me want to stop in my tracks.  I had the surgery about 7 months ago.  I'm wondering if it's scar tissue or if something else is going on in there.  I'm supposed to go for my follow-up digital mammo tomorrow - so I will discuss it  with my breast sugeon afterwards.  I'll let you know what she says and what the results are. Carol
Posts.Title: Tenderness in nipple 2 months after biopsy? barb3246 artsci1

Also, I know asthma is nothing to play with - some of my close relatives have it, so you have to let them know what happened the last time you had anesthesia!  When they took out my lumps, I was off for a few days; it may depend on what they find, but I'm not sure.  I hope all goes well for you, and if you need to vent some more then you know where to come for support

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2009 11:47AM artsci1 wrote: Hi armysmurf, I too have fibrocystic breasts.  It is good that you have an appointment because that is the only real way to find out what is going on.  It could be an infection or a cyst - I personally had a couple fibroadenomas and cysts.  It's best not to guess though, and whatever the outcome (hopefully benign!), you have come to a wonderful place for support.  Take care and keep us informed.
Posts.Title: Have lumps HELP armysmurf artsci1

The stromal fibrosis can make lumps look malignant even when they are not! I know waiting is hard, but remember we are here when you need to talk or  vent.  Please keep us updated.

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2009 11:16AM artsci1 wrote: Hi sueelizabeth, I had surgery  a little over 6 months ago.  It went very well !  The scar is so small - hardly noticeable.  The shape of my breast is the same and I actually had two lump removed different locations.  My surgeon did a great job.  Try not to be too scared - just try to make sure they have some experience.  Let us know how it goes.  Praying you have b9 results!!
Posts.Title: new here - worried, please read sueelizabeth676 sueelizabeth676

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2010 04:13PM artsci1 wrote: Hi georgie_girl, I am waiting too for my six month follow-up(4 months left).  They found another lump.  I have already had 2 removed with a surgery about 1-1/2 years ago.  My lumps looked funny - especially one, but it/they ended up being benign.  I made myself crazy back then - checking and rechecking films, etc... I did learn a whole lot though - you would have thought that I took a radiology class(lol).  A little humor keeps me sane - seriously! I am not sure what is up with your GP not believing in mammos maybe you can suggest ultrasounds or possibly find another GP...?  I do understand about family history of certain types of cancers related to breast cancer because my sister died from uterine/ovarian cancer - I do not know which was the primary cancer.  It was aggressive, and it spread fast...she was only 42  : (  That was 8 years ago.  I am now 44, so when I found those lumps when I was 42, I was worried.  My aunt also had ovarian cancer in her early 50's - she passed away too.  So, I understand your fears. I tell myself all the time that worrying doesn't change anything(I know, easier said than done!), so I just try to stay proactive, smile and laugh as often as I can, pray, and fight the good fight when I need to! If you still need to yell - go ahead - I am here.  We all are!  Keep us posted.
Posts.Title: STUPID! georgie_girl wyldblumusic

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2009 11:39AM artsci1 wrote: Hi kgoodfl, I haven't had an experience quite like yours, but I did have a couple of lumps removed.  Doctors thought it may be cancer at first because I had an fna come back showing some atypical cells and worrisome looking films which later was found to be stromal fibrosis which makes benign lumps look malignant.  So, yours could still be benign.  Unfortunately, you have to play the wait and see game.  I hate that game!  It could be scar tissue that they see and feel.  I understand why you want to prepare yourself because who wants to be blindsided - especially because of your mother.  I can somewhat relate because my sister passed away from ovarian/uterine cancer at age 42.  However, in the midst of preparing yourself, try not to get too down or negative - maybe just tell yourself, whatever the outcome I'm going to deal with it - and if I need to fight then I'll fight hard!!  Then just keep living your life to the fullest enjoying every possible moment !!  Let us know what happens - we are here to support you. : )

Good luck and let us know what you decide to do.

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2009 03:58PM artsci1 wrote: Thanks mommy2baz, I appreciate the condolensces.  It's been 7 years since my sister passed away.  I still miss her like crazy.  She was my best friend.  Cancer does suck!!!  We just have to keep fighting cancer  - kicking its' butt !!!  We have to make every day count !!!  Have a great weekend and let us know how it's going.
Posts.Title: Breast Tissue "Differences"?? mommy2baz MelissaA

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2009 01:33PM artsci1 wrote: Hi taz_in_teen, I just took my 16 year old daughter to the breast doctor about a month ago.  She has very lumpy breasts.  The doctor said that she has some cysts.  I know it can be hard to talk to your mom about these things, but try to just take a deep breath and ask her if she can set up a dr. appt. for you because you are having some problem with your breast.  If you still feel as though you can't talk to her, then perhaps write her a note.  Although not impossible, breast cancer is very rare for your age.  It is better to know what is happening!
Posts.Title: a scared teenager taz_in_teen apple

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2009 09:32AM artsci1 wrote: Hi again taz_in_teen, I understand your concern about stressing your mom out more.  If your breast has been like that since as long as you can remember, it may just be how your breast is shaped.  Also if you have pain in both breasts, it could be hormonal.  See if the pain comes right before you period.  But, maybe you can try just to ask her to set up a regular dr.'s appointment for a checkup, and you can talk to your regular doctor about it, and then maybe he or she can tell you whether you should be concerned or not.  I understand about you being shy and introverted, because I was too. !  I had to force myself to do certain things that were "ouside my comfort zone"  It helped me to slowly grow out of the shyness !  It was not always easy, but it was well worth it.  When things like your health are at stake, then sometimes you have to take a deep breath and push past the uneasiness.  If you need to talk some more, I am here.
Posts.Title: a scared teenager taz_in_teen apple

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2010 02:26PM artsci1 wrote: Hi Nouly, I don't know if you have seen it or not, but there is a High Risk Women forum listed right underneath Not Diagnosed But Worried.  In that forum, they have some women talking about their diagnosis of ALH and ADH whether they will use the Tamoxifen or monitor.  I know it is such a personal decision, but it did seem quite insightful and helpful.  I hope this helps. Take care
Posts.Title: when to do MRI after ALH diagnosis? nouly leaf

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2009 12:28PM artsci1 wrote: Hi mommy2baz, I am sorry that they are putting you though all that.  It's good that you are switching doctors and facility.   About 3 weeks ago, I had my 6 month post op follow up digital mammogram (from that lump removal - b9 results).  I too have dense breast.  At first they thought they saw something, so they took more pictures.  It turned out to be breast tissue that compressed with more views, so they said that everything was fine.  I don't have to go back for another year. I still have to get my pelvic ultrasound to check out my ovaries - remember to ask about getting the CA-125 test when you go about the ovarian pain. Take care, and I hope to talk to you soon. Carol
Posts.Title: Breast Tissue "Differences"?? mommy2baz MelissaA

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2008 09:14PM artsci1 wrote: Hi moby, Try not to freak out too much.  I've been where you are.  It doesn't make the time go by any faster.  I've tried it(smile).  Try to keep yourself busy.  Also, sometimes we don't feel wat the doctor's may feel cause they know what they are feeling/looking for.  We are supposed to do self exams so that we get to know our breasts - then we will be aware if they get lumpier or hardeTry to remember  to think of and do other things while you wait for your mammogram.
Posts.Title: doctor says I need a mammogram moby Dukemom2

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2009 11:56AM artsci1 wrote: Hi mommy2baz,  I had surgery for a lump.  At first they didn't know what it was, the doctors thought it may be cancerous because it had a funny shape - it was weird.  Then I had all these conflicting results, so the lump had to come out.  I had stromal fibrosis which makes an area look possibly cancerous, but it was a fibroadenoma.  I'm thinking that in your case, maybe they are seeing scar tissue from the surgery? !  Did they compare the previous films - that is very important.  I too have intermittent pain in the area of the surgery.  They say that it is the nerve mending itself.  I also have had the transvaginal u/s - supposed to be having another one soon actually - I had pains where my right ovary is - so bad that sometimes it would stop me in my tracks!!  I did have a partial hysterectemy before this ( horrible fibroids - my uterus was a total mess ) - I still have my ovaries.  The doctor thinks that the pain is caused by scar tissue, but they aren't sure so I get the u/s.  The doctors check me frequently because of family history; my aunt died of ovarian cancer in her late 40's, and my sister died of ovarian/uterine cancer at the age of 42.  I'm 42 now.  They can't always see everything transvaginally.  Please get the MRI !!  I'm not trying to scare you, but please don't leave it to chance.  Please feel free to ask me any questions.  Take care.
Posts.Title: Breast Tissue "Differences"?? mommy2baz MelissaA
